CatDescriptText: Earl Shoffner, railway mail clerk, St. Louis and Douglas J. Robinson, Pullman porter, Schenley Heights, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 18, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe that Patrice Lumumba, deposed Premier, was a good or evil influence on the Congo, in his quest for the natives to rule themselves?  Do you believe his slaying was justified?"  Mr. Shoffner's answer reads: "It's a hard question to answer.  Lumumba seems to me to blow hot and cold...Ultimately, he was a bad influence...The slaying was definitely not right."  Mr. Robinson's answer reads: "I think he was a good influence, as good as they have...No man's slaying is justified.  he was mobbed.  Every man should have a chance at justice, and not be put to death by violence."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Earl Shoffner wearing hat, eyeglasses, and plaid coat, standing in front of Western Union, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Douglas J. Robinson wearing hat, eyeglasses, and herringbone coat, standing in front of ribbed metal wall, Smithfield Street, Downtown
